name: Epidural Spinal Cord Stimulation
summary: A neuromodulation technique involving the implantation of electrodes over the spinal cord's dura mater to deliver targeted electrical stimulation, used to manage chronic pain and aid motor recovery after spinal cord injury.
description: Epidural spinal cord stimulation (SCS) involves surgically implanting electrodes in the epidural space above the spinal cord to deliver electrical impulses. This therapy modulates nerve signals before they reach the brain, reducing chronic pain or enhancing motor function after neurological injury. It is typically reserved for patients who have not responded to conservative treatments.

delivery_methods: Implanted pulse generator with percutaneous or paddle leads

primary_indications: Motor recovery after spinal cord injury
off_label_uses: Enhancement of autonomic function post-spinal cord injury
clinical_metadata.safety_profile: Generally safe with appropriate patient selection; surgical and device-related risks present.
clinical_metadata.evidence_level: Moderate to high for chronic pain; emerging for motor recovery.
clinical_metadata.research_support: Multiple randomized trials support efficacy in chronic pain; small trials show promise for SCI motor recovery.

items: Persistent neuropathic pain unresponsive to medication and less invasive therapies
Motor rehabilitation in selected spinal cord injury patients

sections.text: Electrical stimulation of the dorsal columns of the spinal cord alters pain signal transmission and may modulate spinal and supraspinal circuits to promote motor function.

sections.preparation: Patient undergoes trial stimulation period to assess benefit before permanent implantation.
procedure: Placement of trial leads into the epidural space under fluoroscopic guidance
External pulse generator connected for trial phase (5–7 days)
If successful, surgical implantation of permanent leads and pulse generator
sections.duration: Long-term therapy with follow-up programming sessions

sections.pre_session: Trial period lead placement and patient education.
sections.treatment_phase: Continuous electrical stimulation via implanted device.
sections.post_session: Follow-up visits for device programming and troubleshooting.

long_term: Possible motor function improvement in SCI

ideal_candidates: Patients with intractable neuropathic pain unresponsive to conservative measures

facility: Hospital or surgical center with neuromodulation capability

studies: Kumar K, et al. Spinal cord stimulation in treatment of chronic benign pain: challenges in treatment planning and present status, a 22-year experience. Neurosurgery. 2006;58(3):481–496.
Angeli CA, et al. Recovery of over-ground walking after chronic motor complete spinal cord injury. N Engl J Med. 2018;379(13):1244–1250.
sections.limitations: High upfront cost; effectiveness depends on patient adherence and device maintenance.

sections.insurance_coverage: Often covered for chronic pain indications; experimental for motor recovery
sections.cost_effectiveness: High for select chronic pain patients

sections.adolescents: Consider only in refractory chronic pain with multidisciplinary review.
sections.elderly: Generally safe with careful surgical risk assessment.
sections.comorbidities: Modify approach for patients with cardiac devices or coagulation disorders.

items: Trial stimulation is essential before permanent implant to ensure benefit.
Programming adjustments may be needed over time for optimal effect.
Device battery replacement required every 5–10 years.

seo.title: Epidural Spinal Cord Stimulation
seo.description: Epidural spinal cord stimulation is an implantable neuromodulation therapy for chronic pain and motor recovery after spinal cord injury.
